importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the presidential election results announcement and the official start of the new administration in Bolivia.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The economic crisis in Bolivia, including currency shortages, inflation, and fuel shortages, has been ongoing since 2023, setting the stage for the political shift and the challenges faced by the new president.

keyTakeAways: Rodrigo Paz won Bolivia's presidential election with 54% of the vote, defeating former President Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga who received 45%.
Paz, a centrist senator from the Christian Democratic Party, emerged from obscurity to win, representing a significant political shift away from the long-ruling Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) party.
Paz’s victory reflects widespread public frustration with economic mismanagement, inflation, and the perceived unresponsiveness of the MAS government over 20 years.
Paz’s running mate, former police officer Edman Lara, gained traction through viral social media presence and anti-corruption activism, resonating with working-class and rural voters.

Paz plans to end Bolivia’s fixed exchange rate, reduce fuel subsidies, and cut public investment, marking a shift from MAS’s economic model, while promising to maintain social benefits and implement reforms gradually.
Bolivia faces severe economic challenges, including a 23% year-on-year inflation rate, fuel shortages, and a dollar shortage that has crippled imports and savings.
Paz has pledged to avoid the International Monetary Fund, instead relying on anti-corruption measures and restoring confidence in the currency to attract foreign savings.
Criticism exists over Paz’s vague promises of financial support for the poor during subsidy cuts, with some voters calling for more concrete economic reforms.
The election reflects a clear class divide: Paz won in Indigenous and working-class regions, while Quiroga won among wealthier, politically established elites in Santa Cruz.
The victory marks a potential shift toward a more market-oriented economy in Bolivia after two decades of MAS-led socialist policies.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Rodrigo Paz, a centrist senator who rose from political obscurity, won Bolivia’s presidential election with 54% of the vote, defeating former President Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga, who received 45%. The victory marks a significant shift away from two decades of Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) rule, driven by public anger over economic collapse, inflation, and the perceived mismanagement of public resources. Paz’s campaign, backed by his running mate Edman Lara — a former police officer known for anti-corruption activism — resonated with working-class and Indigenous voters, especially in the Andean highlands. However, the new government faces immense challenges, including a severe dollar shortage, fuel shortages, and a 23% inflation rate. Paz has pledged to end the fixed exchange rate, cut fuel subsidies, and reduce public spending, while avoiding the IMF and promising gradual reforms. Though he aims to maintain social benefits, his vague promises of financial support have drawn criticism. The election reflects a deep class divide, with Paz winning among rural and Indigenous communities and Quiroga among wealthier, politically entrenched elites in Santa Cruz. This shift signals a potential turning point in Bolivia’s economic and political trajectory, though the success of reforms remains uncertain.
title: Rodrigo Paz Wins Bolivia’s Presidential Election Amid Economic Crisis
